newsitem.title: UGANDA: Uganda's coffee goes to U.S. speciality market.
newsitem.headline: Uganda's coffee goes to U.S. speciality market.

text.p: Uganda's prime washed arabica coffees will be presented to a speciality coffee conference in New Orleans, Florida, in April as part of Uganda's drive to gain a foothold in the lucrative speciality market.

"Last week, we concluded a deal with the Speciality Coffee Association of the U.S. which has admitted Uganda's prime washed coffee from Bugisu into the speciality movement," Uganda Coffee Trade Federation (UCTF) executive director Fred Kawuma said.
The Bugisu coffee will be marketed by Aproma, the Brussels-based association that promotes coffee trade between African Caribbean Countries (ACP) and the European Union.

Aproma recently concluded a study in the U.S. and Uganda on the potential international demand for Ugandan washed coffees. It has also been working on generic promotions in Kenya, Ethiopia and Tanzania, according to UCTF officials.
"Next year when Aproma presents its originals, Uganda will be one of them," Kawuma told Reuters.
Bugisu washed coffees, which grow at the foot of Mount Elgon, near the Kenyan border in eastern Uganda, are the best of the country's arabicas.
The Bugisu coffee will have four selected origins: Buginyana, Bulago, Bulecheke and Sebei -- based on quality displayed during the Aproma study.
"It is very important for exporters of that coffee to participate at that show," said Kawuma.
Uganda's admission to the speciality market meant exporters of the Bugisu would be able to get premiums, he said.
Bugisu coffee is currently sold at a discount of about 30 cents to other types at the Grade C level.

Kawuma said the Uganda Coffee Development Authority (UCDA) would be charged with ensuring that the Bugisu coffee met international requirements. UCDA would have to modernise testing facilities to be able to cope, he added.
About 70 percent of Uganda's coffee exports, which totalled 4.1 million bags in 1995/96, go to European Union countries.
